title: Cat. 121  Bust of a Nude Woman and Three-Quarter Figure of a Man with a White Cap in Profile, Third Small Figure at Far Right, 1899
publication_title: Gauguin Paintings, Sculpture, and Graphic Works at the Art Institute of Chicago
content:
<section class="osci-tk-epub-section tombstone" id="tombstone">Bust of a Nude Woman and Three-Quarter Figure of a Man with a White Cap in Profile, Third Small Figure at Far Right, headpiece for Le sourire (The Smile)  
1899/1900  
Only state  
Wood-block print in black ink on cream wove paper; 103 × 182 mm (image); 119 × 260 mm (sheet)  
The Art Institute of Chicago, gift of Mr. Cornelius Crane, 1946.425  
Guérin 73, Kornfeld 68  
Fot the verso, see fig. 121.1

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section technical_report" id="technical_report">Gauguin carved interchangeable vignettes to accompany the text of his self-published journal, Le sourire (The Smile). Here it is likely that the male figure is a self-portrait in profile of the artist himself. Other such self-depictions are discernible by the emphasis that the artist places on his aquiline nose and pointed chin (e.g., fig. 121.2 [cat. 116] and fig. 121.3). He is silhouetted by a simplified version of the winged lizard that appears behind the female nude in Nave nave fenua (cat. 56). Gauguin used a small piece of coarsely grained wood to carve this image. As in his Suite of Late Wood-Block Prints (cats. 91–105), this piece of wood likely derived from an indigenous source that Gauguin himself prepared for carving and printing.

This print was never realized as a headpiece in any of the nine published issues of Le sourire. In the facsimile edition it is reproduced among a group of six wood-block prints, none of which appeared paired with text in any of the published issues of the journal.

The block was inked in black ink that contained a significant amount of binder. This is represented by faint halos around the printed lines and the reticulated pattern of ink deposition. These characteristics are most indicative of an oil such as linseed that was added to the ink to obtain the desired viscosity and working properties.

The paper is a poor quality, machine-made wove paper. It was hand torn along the top edge. The long horizontal format suggests that a larger sheet was used to print multiple blocks at the same time, after which it was separated into several hand-torn sections. This format is alluded to on page 186 of Gauguin’s Noa Noa—Voyage de Tahiti. Gauguin adhered an impression of this print onto a page that also contains At the Black Rocks (cat. 91) and Two Women Chattering (fig. 121.4 [cat. 113]). Thissuggests that they held particular significance for him; in addition, the vertical stacking of three images may well point to the artist’s method of printing several blocks concurrently on this type of paper.

In anticipation of this publication, the print was conserved to reduce discoloration and structurally stabilize the work. Over time, the paper had become quite golden yellow in tone. Additionally, severe discoloration along the left and right edges occurred due to contact with acidic materials. Successful conservation intervention resulted in a more even sheet tone overall.

The print is in excellent condition.  
Mary Broadway and Harriet K. Stratis

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section provenance" id="provenance">Dr. Victor Segalen (1878–1919), Paris.

By descent, to his wife, Yvonne Segalen (née Hébert) (1890–1968).

Given by Yvonne Segalen to Dr. Rabinovitch (died 1946), San Francisco, in 1932.

By descent from Dr. Rabinovitch to his son-in-law, M. Mordvinoff.

Sold by M. Mordvinoff to Cornelius Crane (1905–1962), New York.

Given by Cornelius Crane to the Art Institute of Chicago, 1946.

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section references" id="references">Marcel Guérin, L’oeuvre gravé de Gauguin (H. Floury, 1927; Alan Wofsy Fine Arts, 1980), cat. 73 (ill.).

Elizabeth Mongan, Eberhard W. Kornfeld, and Harold Joachim, Paul Gauguin: Catalogue Raisonné of His Prints, with assistance of Christine H. Stauffer (Galerie Kornfeld, 1988), p. 242, cat. 68.

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section other_documentation" id="other_documentation">Inscribed in wood block, upper left, printed in black ink: P / G

Inscribed in wood block, center left, printed in black ink: 3 RAIRA

Collector’s mark, lower left, in graphite: VS

The nature of the media and their application, as well as the condition of the artwork, were assessed through visual examination using normal, transmitted, and raking light; microscope magnification (80–300×); and ultraviolet-light examination (254 and 365 nm).

</section><section epub:type="footnotes" id="footnotes">Paul Gauguin, “Le sourire” de Paul Gauguin, with an introduction by L. G. Bouge, facsimile ed. (G.-P. Maisonneuve, 1952), p. E, no. VIII.

Liz Sorokin, condition report and treatment record, Apr. 2015, conservation object file, Department of Prints and Drawings, Art Institute of Chicago.

Cornelius Crane, New York, to Carl O. Schniewind, Art Institute of Chicago, Nov. 9, 1946, photocopy, correspondence, curatorial object file, Art Institute of Chicago. His initials, in graphite, on verso of print. See Inscriptions and Distinguishing Marks.

Cornelius Crane, New York, to Carl O. Schniewind, Art Institute of Chicago, Nov. 9, 1946.

Dr. Rabinovitch was a family friend of the Segalens. Cornelius Crane, New York, to Carl O. Schniewind, Art Institute of Chicago, Nov. 9, 1946, photocopy, correspondence, curatorial object file, Art Institute of Chicago.

The collector’s mark of Victor Segalen.

fig. 121.3 Paul Gauguin (French, 1848–1903). Tahitians, 1894. Watercolor monotype on Japanese paper; 24 × 20 cm (9 7/16 × 7 7/8 in.). British Museum, 1949, 0411.3675.

fig. 121.4 Paul Gauguin (French, 1848–1903). Impression of Bust of a Nude Woman and Three-Quarter Figure of a Man with a White Cap in Profile, Third Small Figure at Far Right, pasted onto fol. 97V middle, from the bound manuscript Noa Noa, Voyage de Tahiti, 1893–1901. Musée d’Orsay, Paris, held by the Département des Arts Graphiques, Musée du Louvre, Paris, gift of Georges-Daniel de Monfreid and the sons of the artist “in memory of their sister,” 1927, RF 7259.53.

fig. 121.1 Verso of Gauguin’s Bust of a Nude Woman and Three-Quarter Figure of a Man with a White Cap in Profile, Third Small Figure at Far Right, headpiece for Le sourire (The Smile) (1899/1900). The Art Institute of Chicago, 1946.425.
